Posted: August 16, 2015
												I found this to be a very insteresting game. I didn't pay any attention to it at first, and got it as a part of bundle when it was on sale, and it took my brother to launch it and play a bit for me to realise that it's the exact game I'd like to play.tl;dr: I fell in love with it from the first actual sight :DGameplay here is like an old arcade, you have 5 buttons to satisfy all you needs, left/right+jump, teleport bullet and damaging bullet,It's easy to learn and pretty easy to go through, especially since game is pretty short (you can see that it can be finished under 20 minutes, took me ~15 on my first and last speed run). But if you want to uncover all the secrets that this game has you'll need to put your mind and reflexes into it. Most, if not all, secret places are spottable if you know where to look, but getting there might become the real problem there.I quite enjoyed the ride, even though it lasted only 4 hours for me to get all the achievements and find all the secrets. I still recommend it, especially if it's on sale.Overall: 10 secret gun upgrades out of 10

Posted: August 15, 2015
												I bought this game not thinking very much of it at the time. When I got into the game my view for Out There Somewhere changed drastically. I found myself loving this game. Out There Somewhere mixes a bullet hell arcade shooter with a platformer. All of this is done with well crafted sprites and backgrounds and is accompanied by a stellar 8 bit soundtrack that never seems to get repetitive.Out There Somewhere excells with its platforming and space combat. However the platforming combat was quite dull and the characters movements were a bit sharp at times. Beyond that the teleportation gun added a fun addition to the 2D platforming style and allowed there to be puzzles in the game.The game is about an hour long but has replay value for those who want to complete everything. When I got stuck on certain areas I wasn't stuck for long as the puzzles are relatively easy. Overall I enjoyed this game and I recommend this game to all platforming fans, 8bit fans and indie fans. Out There Somewhere is a fun twist on the classic 8bit metroidvania platformer.Score: 7/10While having good graphics and a great soundtrack the platforming was a bit stiff and this game does not stand out from others of the same genre, but still a fun game nonetheless.

Posted: March 17, 2016
												If you're a fan of pixel art platform games there is no excuse not getting this game. It is pretty short but it's very appropriately priced and it has great replay value. The controls and mechanics are very fluid and the difficulty is well balanced; it's challenging but it never feels frustrating. 												I've only played it a little bit, but so far I'm loving it.Great ship shooting gameplay, great platformer aspects, amazing soundtrack, there's a million things I like about this game.One thing I didn't like is that you can sometimes miss checkpoints, which causes a lot of backtracking. Also, when you first unlock the weapon that actually hurts enemies, it does little to no damage (considering it's a one-hit KO on you), and one of the first enemies you face after getting the gun is one that flies around trying to get you. It makes it a lot harder when those ones are around.It's still a great game.8/10

Posted: March 15, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a puzzle game akin to Swapper, VVVVV, Portal, and any number of other games where there is a gimmick to move your playable character through puzzle environments.   Here you play as a tiny spaceman as he shoots rounds from his gun that instantly teleport him when the round hits a surface.  There are many different elements that flesh out gameplay like timed blocks, metal grates, beams that stop the round, beams that bend the round, beams that reflect the round, etc.   Your objective is nothing more than to reach the other side of the room so that you can journey on and collect space components to repair your spaceship. The graphics are pretty simple but are charming in their own right.  It's just some dark alien tileset and the enemies as well as the player are also a tile. Coming from how the game is played you don't need any more. The music is the only downside as nothing is catchy and may get on your nerves quick if you don't like 40 second BGMs from budget gameboy titles repeating over and over. All and all you can do no wrong getting this for under or near 1 USD.  Check this out, it's great fun and pretty addicting.

Posted: August 9, 2016
												Out there somewhere is one of the hidden gems I have found while searching through Steam’s sales, and personally, I enjoyed playing through it.	At first, OTS looks like one of the dime-a-thousand pixel-art 2-d platformers that make up quite a few of the indie games for sale on steam. When investigated further, it is revealed that the game is a bit above the rest.	The main story of the game, is very simple, and is only there because it has to be in order for the game to make sense.	Captain Yuri and crew fight off the evil alien, Grigori, and Yuri goes in alone to stop him, gets shot down, and lands on an alien planet. From there he must repair his ship, and find Grigori to defeat him.	Bland and stereotypical as the story may be, the music is anything but, and ranges from chiptunes to electronic to orchestral. From the moment you launch the game, you are greeted by a dark track that gets you in the mood to play. While it may not be as memorable as Level one of Mario, or the Legend of Zelda theme, the music is still catchy, and because the soundtrack is $0.99 DLC, I listen to it in my spare time, in fact while writing this review I have actually been listening to the music to get in the spirit.	The actual meat of this game centers around teleportation and momentum to solve puzzles. There are two side-scrolling shooter portions, but I’ll get to those later. You are given two guns at the start of the game, the teleportation gun, and the regular gun, with one heart, and one direction to go, right.  The main focus is of course the teleportation gun, which has momentum mechanics, basically, if you jump right before your shot hits a wall, you jump when you teleport there. There are also three beams and various blocks/mirrors that affect how your shot will land. Overall, the puzzle section is definitely solid. There are various power-ups, ship upgrades, and heart/health containers that you can find in capsules by exploring, but they are not necessary to beat the game.	The first time I played through, it took me 2 ½ hours, without picking up any capsules. The game contains plenty for a short amount of time though; there are two ship battles with Grigori, where the parts you collected come into play, and one boss fight that uses the mechanics you’ve learned throughout the game, to go along with the puzzles and side-scrolling.	For the price I bought it, I believe that the game is very good, with a few flaws here and there, and deserves a solid:8/10

Posted: September 5, 2015
												This game is everything I have ever wanted in a short, cheap Metroidvania puzzle platformer. Don't buy it for $5, but for $0.19 it's a steal. A very cool and not at all gimmicky teleport gun mechanic, controller support, and a campaign that takes 90-120 min if you don't know what you're doing, 60-90 min to 100% if you know what you're doing, and 15-25 min to speedrun if you know what you're doing. I've played through the game start to finish about 5-7 times and I still don't have all the achievements. The collectibles are extremely fun and there's only one that I had to look up where to find it (the 11th core). All in all, I recommend this game to any fan of Metroidvania games and puzzle platformers. My only complaint is that backtracking is severely limited, but it's OK because the game is so short. Great replayability, great value, great game. 9/10.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												*NOTE: This review was written by an individual who purchased the item at the time when it was  obscenely discounted (96%)!*Portal + Metroid (NES) = Out There Somewhere.  This was a great little game, and I would have loved to have seen it last longer.  It took me about 2 hours to beat the game, but there is a marginal amount of replayability if you push for acquiring all of the Steam achievements.The game is 2D Metroid (NES) style and is very linear, with a few optional detours for special items if you feel up to it.  Each side-scrolling screen you pass into plays out as increasingly difficult Portal-type, platforming puzzles.  Near the 2/3 mark of the game, there were perhaps 2 screens that were difficult enough that I had to cave in and check a walkthrough for and when I found the answer, it was a slap-upside-the-head DERP answer I felt like I should have obviously known, but some spots do require some brain-power, which were refreshing.*DISCLAIMER: Everyone and their dead dog needs to buy this game while it is only 19 cents to purchase!  That being said, although it is a ton of fun, I personally would not recommend it for the full $4.99 price tag due to the overall lack of bang for your buck.*

Posted: June 18, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is an action-platformer where the primary gimmick is a gun that teleports you to where you shoot it. It's quite short — my first playthrough clocked in at just over an hour — but even so there's a surprising amount of depth in the game's platforming challenges, as well as a few secrets here and there to discover. I legitimately tried looking for as many as I could in that first playthrough, only to discover at the end that I had missed around half of them. Additionally, for the speedrun inclined, there is an option to display a timer, and it is entirely possible to finish the game in about 11 minutes.The game doesn't feature a complicated plot — it's the simple tale of a space cop who has to shoot up an evil alien dude. If you're a huge nostalgic memelord you might enjoy the blatant Zero Wing references. Graphically, the game resembles Cave Story with extra frames of fluidity added to the sprite animations. It's nice to look at in general, and the alien friends are charming. The chiptune music is also pretty good, save for one annoying track near the beginning of the game that seemed to only last like 20 seconds before looping.There are several minor issues I suppose I should mention. For one, there are many screens that cannot be returned to once they're left, and frequent checkpoints, while normally a boon, mean that if you've missed a collectible, you've probably also lost the opportunity to get it. Considering that health upgrades are part of these collectibles and you only have one health to begin with, it is entirely possible to end up past a point of no return where you have to finish the game as a one-hit-wonder, or just restart because it's too annoying to handle.Along with that, there's also an achievement that requires having 30 teleport gun shots on screen at once; the only apparent way to do that causes a cacophony of ear-piercing sound effects unless the game is muted. I can't imagine this being an oversight, and since I'm a jerk I found it sort of amusing, but still ow.Nitpicking aside, Out There Somewhere is a solid title for anyone in want of bite-sized platforming fun. It is also literally $0.19 during the Steam Summer Sale, and the 3 Steam Trading Cards it drops should recoup the bulk of that price. This game is a must buy before the sale ends.p.s. i just noticed that the developer's logo mascot changes colors on every start up and that is an odd feature i don't know if anyone but me would notice but i like it thank you

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Fun little game with a great soundtrack and game mechanics.  It's challenging enough to keep you thinking but not rage inducing like some other games. Posted: July 1, 2015
												Short and sweet puzzle-platformer - the mechanics are built around one superb idea, and - quite a relief after several bad experiences - the controls are snappy and responsive.The aim of the game is to navigate through various screens to get an important part of your spaceship. Beside walking and jumping, you have a teleport gun - it fires a blue projectile horizontally, and where it hits, there you'll be teleported. Teleportation maintains the momentum you have at the moment when the projectile hits - that opens up a boarload of navigation puzzle opportunities, which are thoroughly explored by the game designers.The game has a cute 8-bit-ish soundtrack that you'll either love or hate - I happen to love it.Out There Somewhere is an ideal casual game - short (1-2 hours), not too difficult but not trivial, and thoroughly enjoyable. Worth maybe a couple of EUR / USD - at the 0.20 I got it, it's a steal.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												I don't agree that this game is anything like Super Metroid or Cave Story. Don't expect to upgrade your teleporter or gun, gain extra abilties like double jumping or branch into different areas as I have not encountered anything like that half an hour into the game but do not be surpirsed if it does show up. If anything, I would describe it as Super Meat Boy (Lite!) with Portal, although with a different physics mechinic in place of flinging.It's not kidding when it describes its other elements, though. It really is a refliex-heavy game. Often, the player may solve the puzzle long before he or she actually completes it because of the timing and aim required for the exeuction. It's honestly pretty satisifying, as a result, to get through a room because I managed to not only figure out the crazy, over-elobrate plan where I need to let some beam idle for 4.5 seconds before activating the second beam, destorying a boulder on the far right, teleporting to a platform on the left using the first teleporter, waiting for the first beam to deactivate (as beams block each other), and then using the second beam to get to the door.  This, however, can be frustrating if a player wishes to rush through the game or something. That is all the game has going for it.The chiptune music doesn't really motivate players to take their time, being ridicalously reptitive and loud, and the setting and story isn't memorable or worth paying attention to so far in my playthrough. I do not even know the name of my pro- oh, it's Yuri. My male protagonist's name is a common tag for lesbian storylines in manga. Hooray. The artstyle is, well, more of what you see can see in the store page.It's fun but nothing more than an extended flash game to me. It doesn't have the humor of Portal and so the only really motivating to keep playing is to complete more puzzles. Get it when it goes on sale for less than 50 cents.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												First off, I bought this game on a whim for when it was only 19 cents, because I had some spare money from the steam sale, and this looked like something that wasn't a ripoff of Minecraft, see 7 cent 'Uncrowded'.I played it through to completion, and though while the puzzles are phenomenal, using a set of mechanics that really support the platforming, and give a whole new spin on it by the end, there are somethings I dislike about this game, and will mention below.First off, all the tacked on mechanics, i.e. the space battles, which are the first and last things that happen in the game.  They're contrived, really have no point, and if the game ended with the final battle that tested your skills, then that would be amazing, not the 'This is my final form' bs.And second off, the story will rub you the wrong way.  It will.  I recommend skipping all the dialogue, because its a McGuffin plot that thinks it's more than that.  (See risk of rain plot development, or lack thereof)Buy this game on sale, if nothing else.  Its short 2-3 hour campaign is just long enough to excite, and leaves you eager for more.

Done in an 8-bit fassion, and done well tooGameplay- Also done well. It gave me a portalgasm, and that's always goodDifficulty- My main man, fair challenge. Enemies are better avoided than fought, and the platforming is very dynamic and will take any gamer several tries at some point. And in the whole game, I didn't die once where I didn't think it was my own fault.Price- At 19 cents, totes worth it. At 2 bucks however, not so much. It was short, but amazing, I played it in one sitting, but I think 1$-$1.50 is a fair price.Overall: 8/8 Best indie game I've played in awhile.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												             One late night, 'Cave Story' wandred into the house, drunk as usual. 'Portal 2' looked up from her magazine, to see the love of her life stumble in through the front door. 'You Have to Win the Game' and 'Risk of Rain' were already asleep, 'Cave Story' arived home too late to say goodnight to either of them. 'Portal 2' looked up at the love of her life and said, "Were have you been?" 'Cave Story' looked up, as if surprised to be asked a question as such. "I was... just out with some Mimigma eating some cake an' stuff... you know the usual." 'Cave Story' replied. It was the worst lie about cake that 'Portal 2' had ever heard, and even 'Cave Story' knew it. "Look, I'm sorry, its just that ever sense my fanbase went down, I've never really been the same. We both know how it is..." 'Cave Story' said, without the courage to look 'Portal 2' in the face. "Its alright." 'Portal 2' responded. at this, 'Cave Story' looked up at his wife, as if surprised that she would be so kind to him after what he had done. "I guess we've both had some screw-ups, but we always manage to pull back out of it." 'Cave Story' couldnt believe what he was hearing, afterall, 'Portal 2' was still beautiful to him. Her amazing gameplay, memorable charecters, interesting and intreging puzzles. 'Cave Story' knew he had to make this right. "Look 'Portal 2', I know I've had some screw-ups before, but, what if I make it right for you, tonight." 'Portal 2' blushed at this remark. Even after all this time, she still loved him as if it were the first day they met. 'Cave Story's' amazing gameplay and control, the soundtrack, and the story were enough to make her fall in love with him all over again. "Alright." 'Portal 2' said, "You can make it up to me tonight then. 'Cave Story' smiled and turned off the lights, both of them headed upstairs, and proceded with the game.Nine months later, 'Out There Somewhere' was born.THE END

Posted: April 23, 2016
												This game is worth a lot more than it's price. Don't be fooled by the 199 cent price tag this game is good. Maybe even great. First off the soundtrack, is great, it's refreshing, catchy, and motavating in whatever area you are.While the story is simple, this doesn't really make it worse, as the game is mostly reliant on it's puzzles for quality, and that's a good thing too, because the puzzle are pretty good also. They're all sentered around this portal gun that beams you to wherever the bullets hit. From there, new elements are added to modify gameplay slightly, but overall, the basics are the same. As far as difficulty, this game is a medium, although there will be certain rooms that are so strangely difficult and out of nowhere that you'll be tearing you hair out either trying to find the solution or trying to figure out how to put that solution into action, but most of the time it's a pretty smooth, slightly difficult challange.Overall, I deffinetly recommend this game to anyone who likes platformers.8/10.

Posted: April 22, 2015
												After enjoying completing the game with 100% and just some cards left to collect, I decided to give this fine piece of software a review.So what's this game anyway? Basically it's a platformer, with minor Shoot'em Up parts both at the beginning and the end of the game. Armed with a teleport gun and a space suit you control Captain Yuri on his journey to defeat the evil Grigori.Simple control scheme: arrow keys and 3 others, Z X C by default, Europeans might want to swap Z with Y prior to starting. The game does have controller support, I used a keyboard though and had no problems.Over the course of my several playthroughs and experiments I only encountered 1 or 2 minor bugs you wouldn't experience without specifically looking for it. Even if, none of them was game breaking. Otherwise it's got smooth and clean animations, perfect hitboxes and overall fair difficulty. There's no real tutorial but is streamlined on directs you perfectly through the mechanics, the growing complexity should be no problem for the average player.If you want all achievements though, you're in for a tougher challenge, brace yourself and activate your thinker.As for the design, it's an adorable small indie treasure, you won't get 10 hours of excitement but instead you'll get challenging fun packed into a small platformer. Nothing looks out of place, everything fits into this colourfully bright (but not bilindingly bright) small universe. Even the music is brilliant for such a small game, it's repetetive but it doesn't get boring, this way it's even fun waiting for the "delay" Achievement while doing something else. Only downside is there's no transition when the BGM changes but hey, it's not like that would hurt anyoneMy first playthrough took me an hour and roughly 15 minutes, the only thing that really got on my nerves was clicking through Yuris messages on my playthroughs after the first one...Bottom line: whatever you pay, it's a bargain

												I've never left a review for a game but this an exception.  I picked this game up on a whim, and it didn't disappoint.  While the game is short, especially on subsequent playthroughs, I'd say it's about the length of the first portal game maybe a little shorter.  The gameplay is excellent except a couple spots where you don't realize where a platform is, and I thought the final boss, while fun, was just way too different from the rest of the game.  The music and art style is quite fun, with the few cutscenes having a distinct almost robotech flare to them.  This is a great and fun game, and I highly suggest checking it out, and I look forward to more from Miniboss.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												This is a mix between Portal and Super Metroid.  The controls are tight and the gameplay is original.  Using the portal gun in this game really makes you rethink standard platforming conventions, and when you get the hang of the controls the game is a lot of fun.  I got this game on sale for 19 cents and it was certainly worth more than that.  However, I beat the campaign with many secrets in under an hour, so I'm not sure it is worth the full 5 dollar asking price.  Replayability is in trying to unlock all the secrets, although even unlocking them all during a second playthrough only adds another 30-60 min of gameplay.  In all, this is a really interesting game and I'd certainly recommend it during a sale.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a short, but fun game for a reasonable price.  My experience consisted of a playthrough to beat the game, a playthrough to get all of the non-speed-based achievements, and then a playthrough to beat the game in less than 20 minutes for the last achievement.  The gameplay did not get old during my time playing and by my third playthrough I enjoyed using the mastery of the mechanics to blaze through the game for that last achievement.  Overall, I recommend Out There Somewhere for a fun indie experience.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's a really nice, little game. The pixel art is interesting through adding little effects here and there, like how the background is always moving, yet it's not distracting. It makes a cool visual. The game's setting has an oddly not-so-desolate, metroid-like, planet as a setting, which I'm also a big fan of. Another thing I enjoyed was that all the NPC's were nice little guys, and came some interesting lines, if you went the distance to talk to them. The soundtrack is also really nice, it fits the space theme without being boring. The puzzles (stages that have you use a portal gun to advance) were difficult, but never so hard that I gave up. That was a big one for me, and it probably had to do with how well you could see the puzzle in whole, and the simple mechanics. I really love the puzzles. The story is... not very exisistent. There is some bad guy, Grigori (ugly fellow), who is a total jerk, he blew up your ship, you wreck, so now you have to find him on this planet you wrecked on (I don't know why the bad guy is there, I think we were trying to go to the planet to attack him, buy it's not well explained). It does provide an objective, but it isn't very complicated. In whole, I bought the game for $0.16 (an awesome price), and was surprised. However, the game is really short. My 3 hours were all I needed to beat the game. But, if you're okay with short games, it's a lovely experience. I was only upset at the length to be honest. It feels incomplete,  like a greenlight game. I really want more cool puzzles and funny creatures, but then the games over. I also beleive that with more time it could have a neat little plot to help tie the story together. I just want more. An update with a story that goes somewhere (maybe to other planets) would solve all my issues with this game. There are collectables and an achievement for completing the game under an hour, which make the game more replayable in its defense, but it just won't fill the void.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												             One late night, 'Cave Story' wandred into the house, drunk as usual. 'Portal 2' looked up from her magazine, to see the love of her life stumble in through the front door. 'You Have to Win the Game' and 'Risk of Rain' were already asleep, 'Cave Story' arived home too late to say goodnight to either of them. 'Portal 2' looked up at the love of her life and said, "Were have you been?" 'Cave Story' looked up, as if surprised to be asked a question as such. "I was... just out with some Mimigma eating some cake an' stuff... you know the usual." 'Cave Story' replied. It was the worst lie about cake that 'Portal 2' had ever heard, and even 'Cave Story' knew it. "Look, I'm sorry, its just that ever sense my fanbase went down, I've never really been the same. We both know how it is..." 'Cave Story' said, without the courage to look 'Portal 2' in the face. "Its alright." 'Portal 2' responded. at this, 'Cave Story' looked up at his wife, as if surprised that she would be so kind to him after what he had done. "I guess we've both had some screw-ups, but we always manage to pull back out of it." 'Cave Story' couldnt believe what he was hearing, afterall, 'Portal 2' was still beautiful to him. Her amazing gameplay, memorable charecters, interesting and intreging puzzles. 'Cave Story' knew he had to make this right. "Look 'Portal 2', I know I've had some screw-ups before, but, what if I make it right for you, tonight." 'Portal 2' blushed at this remark. Even after all this time, she still loved him as if it were the first day they met. 'Cave Story's' amazing gameplay and control, the soundtrack, and the story were enough to make her fall in love with him all over again. "Alright." 'Portal 2' said, "You can make it up to me tonight then. 'Cave Story' smiled and turned off the lights, both of them headed upstairs, and proceded with the game.Nine months later, 'Out There Somewhere' was born.THE END

Posted: January 21, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is charming, simple, and tricky without being obnoxious. There's so much potential in the teleport gun mechanic that it's a shame  that the game is so short, but it's a cute, well-made game. For the price, you can't do much better.

Posted: January 19, 2016
												Good platformer that focuses on precision timing. High density of easy and medium difficulty puzzles, no really hard puzzles. Puzzles make good use of the game's unique mechanics and generally feel very fresh and varied. Executing a solution can be very difficult and can get repetitive. Mostly linear with some secret or tricky optional areas. Fast respawn but sometimes areas have checkpoints a minute or two apart, which can introduce a noticable degree of repetition. Art is mixed with some areas having a very atmospheric alien world feel with lots of unique background assets, while some blocks  (such as glass) are crude and don't fit the feel of the rest of the game. I would generally recommend this game to players who enjoy precision puzzle platformers.

Posted: January 16, 2016
												This is an awesome little game! It is a hidden little gem i picked up for $0.21. This is a puzzle platformer that is so fun because the puzzles are very satisfying to solve. At the beginning of the game i was a confused but I quickly picked up the game mechanics due to the games perfect learning curve. In other words when the game teaches a new mechanic, it starts off easy until you are familar with the mechanic, then harder till it becomes secondhand knowledge, and THEN thats when the game shows you the next new mechanic. Of course this is not to say that you will never be stumped at some parts, after all it is what makes a puzzle game a puzzle game and takes some creative thinking BUT is never anything ridiculous to solve. The main part about this game that is kept me so hooked were all the puzzles. The harder puzzles are extreamly satisfying to solve (plenty of "OHHH!!" moments) and secrets are very rewarding to find. The puzzles in this game will never become stale, thats because even though the puzzles are essentially the same, the variations and new mechanics keep it very fun, enjoyable, and interesting to play. One more thing is that great soundtrack, props to them!PROS-Great learning curve-Puzzles never get boring-New Mechanics add depth-Puzzles are very satisfying to solve-Puzzles are so clever (I know i've said it a bunch but I really love the puzzles!!!)-Great price-Secrets keep the game interesting-Never too easy or too hard-Awesome music to play toCONS-None (I can't complain as the game has everything advertised plus much more and FAR exceded my expectations)The game is short and can not really be a con for being so, as it cost me a mere $0.21. (But the game is so awesome that I wanted more)The reason I have more than 4 hours is because I tried to get all the "Abandoned Cores" and "Ancient Artifacts"Bottomline : get this game while it's still on sale, but if it's not... still get it cause it's awesome.P.S The very beginning with the old arcade shooter mini game is an awesome little "backstory" and  an interesting way start off the game and if you survive long enough it will explain what the "Abandoned Cores" do and what the boss looks like (you can't defeat him!)

Posted: January 13, 2016
												Have you ever heard someone say a game is "deceptively simple" and wondered what that means? This game will answer that for you. I can't tell you how many times during the course of play I stopped, smiled, and thought "Huh! Clever!" The main mechanic is somewhat unique, but the implementation and level design is where this game shines. If you stop and think about what you need to accomplish, the "puzzle" solves itself with a little bit of platforming savvy. I say "puzzle" because deep down this is a puzzle game disguised as a platformer. The enemies are just obstacles to overcome as you try to get from A to B. There are plenty of secrets to warrant a second playthrough (though I haven't done that yet), and just a TINY bit of backtracking, so I guess this could loosely be classified as Metroidvania, but it has a personality all its own. This is well worth the price of admission, even though I played through it in a little over an hour.If you have a couple of bucks you were GOING to spend on coffee, skip that and buy this. You'll thank me later.

												Out there somewhere is a simple yet interesting 2d retro platformer. It has some cool mechanics that are easy to understand but hard to master. Posted: August 22, 2016
												It took me 77 minutes to beat the game. But man was that possibly in the top of the best 77 minutes of video gaming I've ever video gamed. The pixelish graphics were nice to look at. The music was really good and added to the vibe. The gameplay was pretty innovative, easy to learn, and most of all fun. I had almost given up in those last 5 minutes because I died to the final boss around 15 times in near rapid succession. But that sense of triumph I felt upon beating the game just cannot be matched. 10/10/10Edit: The game says I beat it in under an hour so that's cool. Everything still applies and I will definitely be going back to attempt 100%

Posted: August 24, 2016
												Time of review: in 2 hours even, last room before the final boss; putting aside b/c bored and ♥♥♥♥ that last puzzle.TL;DR: twitch based puzzle plafomer, think VVVVVV with fancier graphics, no exploration aspect, and different mechanics.1st off: unlike what the tags currently say; this is not in any way a metroidvania, metroidvanias are distinguished by a big focus on exploration, ferreting out secrets, etc. You don't do that in OTS, the game is very linear, backtracking is impossible, etc. Its similar to a metroidvania in the sense that there is just 1 big map... but thats about it.What the game actually is at heart is a fairly difficult puzzle platformer, with a big focus on the platforming, you WILL need some good twitch skills to get thru some of the mid/late game rooms. Think VVVVVV except instead of swapping gravity you jump, shoot, & teleport, and you'll have a good idea.Oh, and also there are space shooter sequences right at the beginning & end.If you want a cheap, short, challenging game to kill a weekend afternoon, this is a good buy. Just be aware its only around 2 hours or so for a playthru, the platforming is very twitch, and it aint got any exploration.

Posted: August 24, 2016
												Hows this for a strange playthrough experience?I bought the game expecting nothing out of a cheap 2D platformer, but it had Trading Cards and Achievements so I thought why not? I started the game up and played through the first few screens until I got stuck at the first puzzle because I'm an idiot and I closed the game. I didn't touch it for a week and a half.Soon I was sitting in my chair hovering my mouse cursor over the 'Refund' button before deciding to launch the game a final time. If I couldn't figure out how to get past the puzzle in 10 minutes, I would get a refund and buy a trading card or something with the $0.49 I spent on the game. I ended up figuring out how to get through the level and I kept playing until the very end of the game. I then regretted not buying the game at full-price after I finished it, when just an hour ago I was about to refund it. It's not a very long game, but I think that's intentional. It's a game that deserves to be disected and studied. I've beaten the game six times in five hours, with one of my playthroughs being as short as 17 minutes and 42 seconds. I still keep going back and beating it again and again. This little indie game has me bewildered. It's addictively fun and perfectly difficult. It's the type of difficulty that doesn't take it easy on you but doesn't discourage you from retrying and you end up hooked. It's just short enough to not get boring too quick and just long enough to stay fresh throughout multiple playthroughs. The puzzles are ridiculously fun to solve while the 8bit score is blasting through your speakers. The game is packed full of secret areas and hidden collectibles that are easy to find if you know the game's tricks. Every single screen you come across has some sort of hidden entrance to a secret zone. The mechanics are inventive, fresh, and tight. The slow-moving projectiles of the portal gun give you time to think where you're going next and pull of some pretty incredible mid-air stunts if you're good enough. The control layout is of a standard arcade cabinent (I played with a controller however). Simplisity is key with this game, and that's not a bad thing.8.4/10 - tl;dr : The game will surprise you. It's packed with secrets and has a great soundtrack. The gameplay is addictively fun and inventive, with that Mario Brothers / Dark Souls type of difficulty that keeps you hooked. Short, but fun to replay over and over again if you're an achievement hunter.NOTE: I got a free Steam Key for another game called "Polarity" when I opened the game the first time. That right there in itself is worth 49 cents in my humble opinion. That, and the free soundtrack folder that comes with the games files.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												I bought Out There Somewhere for 19 cents and then sold the trading cards, so I had already got my use out of it.But then I played it.And I wish I had played full price for it.Beautiful pixel graphics, a wonderful, creative (if slightly repetitive) sound-track, but the platforming in this game is something special. Slightly short, though; I would pay upwards of $20 for a longer sequel of this game.You are Yuri. The evil Space-lord Grigori is plotting world demise, and you must stop him armed with only your little spacecraft, upgrading your ship along the way.Sadly, your attack on his massive spaceship fails. Whether you got shot down during the first wave of his fleet or got taken down by that massive laser on Grigori's ship (NO, YOU CAN'T BEAT HIM. I'VE TRIED.) you crash land on a seemingly in-hospitable planet below. Armed with only your Teleport Gun, you must find a Lightorb, which will fix your ship and let you finally defeat Grigori.Straight away, death threatens you as the obstacles you face are not only creative, but exciting. The only thing I disliked about Portal 2 was how hair-rippingly difficult some of the puzzles were. The puzzles in OTS are fast-paced, involving quick turns, movements, and the use of momentum. This means, that if you jump just before your Tele-bullet hits a wall, you will continue traveling upwards, leaving for some interesting platforming.There are a massive amount of secrets hidden in this game, all which help unlock achievements and make the game easier for you. I won't spoil any of them, obviously. What, you thought you could cheat through by reading this? Ha! No secrets for you.Got a few spare bucks in your wallet? Try Out There Somewhere. You won't regret it.
